frameDefinitions: A Creator creates an artifact that is typically an iconic Representation of an actual or imagined entity or event.
A Creator  produces a physical object which is to serve as a Representation of an actual or imagined entity or event, the Represented.
Generally without overall (translational) motion,  an Agent places a Theme at a location, the Goal, which is profiled.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
These are words relating to filling containers and covering areas with some thing, things or substance, the Theme.
frameExamples: Diagrams must be clearly <t>drawn</t> on construction paper. CNI
Epstein saw the machine-man and <t>carved</t> him in shiny metal.
David <t>placed</t> his briefcase on the floor.
Lionel Hutz <t>coated</t> the wall with paint.
listRoleDefinitions: An individual or individuals that bring the <fen>Representation</fen> into existence.
The entity that is created to represent either iconically or abstractly.
The time at which a <fen>Representation</fen> is created.
The location in which the <fen>Creator</fen> produces the <fen>Representation</fen>.
An individual or individuals that bring the <fen>Representation</fen> into existence.
The entity--which may be a thing, an action or a state--that is represented by the <fen>Representation</fen>.
The time at which a <fen>Representation</fen> is created.
The location in which the artist produces the representation.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person (or other force) that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to move.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the object that changes location during the Placing.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the location where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up. This role is profiled by words in this frame.
<fen>Time</fen> is when the Placing occurs
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the Placing occurs.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the actor who instigates the filling.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the physical object or substance which changes location.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the area or container being filled. Goal is generally the NP Object in this frame.
An event which brings about the filling of the <fen>Goal</fen>.
When the filling occurs.
Where the filling takes place.
listRoleExamples: Supposedly, <fex>the artist</fex> drew the picture from memory.

Most of us know where we took <fex>a photo</fex> but have a harder time remembering the time
we took it.
My brother took this picture in France <fex>almost 10 years ago</fex>, and has recently scanned it in.
I took this picture <fex>in Italy</fex> a couple of weeks ago.
Since <fex>Frans</fex> photographed them ten years ago the population has increased.
When Nadar photographed <fex>her</fex>, Desbordes-Valmore was sixty-eight.
I drew him <fex>at work</fex> a bunch of times, mainly for the amusement of the staff.
<fex>The waiter</fex> placed the food on the table.
The waiter placed <fex>the food</fex> on the table.
The waiter placed the food <fex>on the table</fex>.
Grass , which is sown with clover , provides rich pasture for cattle in summer and the clover is <fex>another plant which</fex> puts nitrogen into the soil .
Smithers had placed the table there <fex>the night before</fex>.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Rev. Lovejoy carefully brushed the rolls <fex>with butter</fex>.
